'For Europe, catching up in the digital sector should not mean deregulating at every turn'
subhead: Under pressure from the US, the European Commission is prepared to ease its legislation to halt its technological decline. But Brussels must resist being boxed into a choice between innovation and regulation and instead highlight its strengths, writes Le Monde columnist Stéphane Lauer.

Foreign interference: Why France is raising its voice and turning to the courts
subhead: Since 2023, French authorities have launched nine investigations into activities such as the posting of propaganda posters, all linked to the war in Ukraine and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The most recent case saw three people charged, including the founder of the pro-Russian advocacy group SOS Donbass.

title: Pope Leo XIV urges young Christians in Lebanon to be 'builders of peace'
subhead: Lebanese youth greeted the pope with fervor on the second day of his visit to this multifaith country.

title: 2026 edition Angoulême International Comics Festival officially canceled
subhead: The organizers announced in a statement released on Monday a decision that had seemed inevitable since the series of withdrawals by authors, publishing houses and public funders.

title: Jodie Foster: 'Without cinema, I would have been rigid, dry and much more solitary'
subhead: 'I wouldn't be where I am today if...' In this series, Le Monde interviews a figure about a decisive moment in their life. The American actress pays tribute to her mother, with whom she shared a close, almost inseparable bond for many years.

The last-minute fight to save Gaza's ancient archaeological treasures
subhead: Amid the vast destruction of the war, a small group of determined individuals fought to save Gaza's archaeological heritage. On September 10, they secured a few hours' reprieve from the Israeli army before a storage depot filled with artifacts was bombed to perform a delicate evacuation – the result of intense, high-level negotiations.

title: The art of being Oscar Wilde's grandson
subhead: As Ireland prepares to mark the 125th anniversary of Oscar Wilde's death, Merlin Holland, his only living descendant, works in France to protect the memory of a man who was long viewed as scandalous.

title: Paris restaurants with a New York attitude
subhead: The French capital has recently seen a wave of New York-style restaurants spring up, from slice shops to delis and red sauce joints. Parisians are flocking to these spots to savor not only a slice of culinary culture but also the enduring myth of the Big Apple.
